message.name: A106
message.say: The first sentence is an example of an event that fits with Rose's personality. She considers the risks involved before taking action.

message.name: A107
message.say: You're right, Jordan. But Rose's unusual behavior in the third sentence is what the author needed to move the plot forward. She takes a risk and tells Agnes who she is! Let's look at the following sentence to decide if it is a a character description or an event.

message.say: We are going to practice connecting the character descriptions and events to the plot. This is one way we can elaborate on the story - or understand information that the writer does not tell us directly.

message.name: A114
message.say: Yes. One is, does this description or event connect to the plot? Another is, how does this event or description connect to the plot?

message.name: A115
message.say: Let's start by reading this story, Rose the Cop. Push the Click to Continue button at the bottom of the passage when you have finished reading. If you like, you can click the green Read Text button at the bottom of the screen and read along with the recording.

message.name: A128
message.say: Nice work with the reading. In this story, there are really only two main characters. There is a protagonist and an antagonist.

message.name: A129
message.say: The protagonist is the hero or character that we want to support. The antagonist is the villain or character that we root against.

message.name: A137
message.say: , who is the protagonist in this story?

message.name: A138
message.say: The protagonist in this story is Rose. We can get a clue from the title, Rose the Cop. We empathize with Rose after reading this story.

message.name: A139
message.say: , the protagonist is the character that the reader or audience wants to support.

message.name: A142
message.say: The antagonist in the story is Agnes. She creates the conflict in the story.

message.name: A143

message.name: A146
message.say: , is this highlighted sentence a character description or an event?

message.name: A147
message.say: This sentence describes Rose's character. So it is a character description.

message.name: A148
message.say: , character descriptions tell us more about a character's personality, physical appearance, motives, and behaviours. Events are the actions that occur in a story.

message.name: A149
message.say: Drag and drop the description or event icon on the highlighted sentence.

message.name: A150
message.say: , we have a description of Rose's character that says Rose was not one to talk to strangers. Based on this description, which of the three highlighted actions seems most unlike Rose?

message.name: A151
message.say: According to this character description, Rose was not a person who talked to strangers. However, in one of the events she tells Agnes that she is a police officer even though she is under cover. This event shouldn't have happened according to Rose's character description.

message.name: A152
message.say: , we know from the description of Rose that she is naturally cautious about talking to strangers. It seems like one of the highlighted events below should not have happened based on that information. Which one do you think it is?

message.name: A153
message.say: Click the correct answer, please.

message.name: A154
message.say: , how does this event connect to the plot?

message.name: A155
message.say: The correct answer is that Rose trusted Agnes because of her appearance. Even though Rose pauses to consider the risk which seems in character, she allows Agnes to join her which seems out of character for Rose. This implies that Rose trusts Agnes.

message.name: A156
message.say: , when Rose pauses to consider the risk, what does she allow to happen?

message.name: A157
message.say: Please click the correct answer among four choices.

message.name: A158
message.say: , is this a character description or an event?

message.name: A159
message.say: This sentence describes what Rose is doing, so it is an event.

message.name: A160
message.say: , events usually refer to something that occurs in a certain situation. Descriptions help us understand what a character or situation is like.

message.name: A161
message.say: Drag and drop the description or event icon on the highlighted sentence.

message.name: A162
message.say: , think about the event above in which Rose is seated comfortably sipping coffee. Which highlighted character description below is connected to the event above?

message.name: A163
message.say: The correct answer is she was always aware of her surroundings when she walked down the street and cautious about every possible wolf that crossed her path. This description makes us think that Rose would be cautious about her surroundings and would watch Joseph.

message.name: A164
message.say: , one description emphasizes that Rose is always aware of her surroundings. The other description lets us know that she is skilled at knowing when people are telling the truth.

message.name: A165
message.say: Please click the correct orange character description below.

message.name: A166
message.say: , is this sentence a character description or an event?

message.name: A167
message.say: Action verbs are good clues for events. This event is crucial to the plot, because Rose realizes that the person she trusted has stolen her wallet.

message.name: A168
message.say: , events usually refer to an action that occurs in this story. Description refers to a static description.

message.say: Drag and drop the description or event icon on the highlighted sentence.

message.say: The correct answer is Rose was distracted and Agnes got away, because Rose looked at Agnes and decided that she must not be the pickpocket based on her appearance.
